revision.text:
{|{{Infobox Aircraft Begin |name = NA-50, NA-68/P-64 |image = File:North American P-64 061024-F-1234P-027.jpg |caption = North American P-64 }}{{Infobox Aircraft Type |type =Fighter |manufacturer =[[North American Aviation]] |designer = |first flight =May 1939 (NA-50)
1 September 1940 (NA-68)Gates, John and Tom Lymburn. [http://museum.eaa.org/collection/aircraft/North%20American%20P-64_NA-50.asp "North American P-64/NA-50 – N840."] ''AirVenture Museum.'' Retrieved: 6 January 2012. |introduced = |retired = 1950 (Peru) |status = |primary user = [[Peruvian Air Force]] |more users = [[United States Army Air Forces]] |produced = |number built =13 |unit cost = |developed from = [[North American NA-16]] |variants with their own articles = }} |} The '''North American P-64''' was the designation assigned by the [[United States Army Air Corps]] (USAAC) to the [[North American Aviation]] '''NA-68''' fighter, an upgraded variant of the '''NA-50''' developed during the late 1930s. Seven NA-50s were purchased by the [[Air Force of Peru|Peruvian Air Force]], which nicknamed it ''Torito'' ("Little Bull"). Six NA-68s ordered by the [[Royal Thai Air Force]] were seized before export by the US government in 1941, after the [[Franco-Thai War]] and growing ties between [[Thailand]] and the [[Empire of Japan]]. These aircraft were used by the USAAC as unarmed fighter trainers. The Peruvian NA-50s subsequently saw action during the [[Ecuadorian-Peruvian War]] of 1941. ==Design and development== ===NA-50=== [[File:North American NA-50 fighter 'Torito'.jpg|thumb|NA-50 "Torito" destined for Peruvian service]] The North American Aviation '''NA-50''' was developed as a simple single-seat, low-wing, single-engined fighter for export. The design was developed from the [[North American NA-16|NA-16]]/[[North American BT-9|BT-9]] basic training aircraft of 1935. The NA-16 evolved into a series of aircraft that were some of the most widely used advanced and basic training aircraft produced by any country, and provided the basic design for a single-engined fighter intended for small countries that needed a simple aircraft with modern capabilities and features. The NA-50 ''Torito'' (Spanish slang for "little bull"), built for Peru, was a single-seat fighter design based on the two-seat Basic Combat Demonstrator NA-44. The NA-50 was powered by an 840 hp (626 kW) Wright R-1820-G3 radial air-cooled [[engine]] that gave the NA-50 a top speed of 295 mph at 9,500 feet. It was armed with two .30 in (7.62 mm) [[M1919 Browning machine gun]]s. The aircraft were manufactured in May 1939, and test-flown at the factory.Green 1961, p. 134. ===NA-68=== In 1940, the [[Royal Thai Air Force]] ordered six aircraft similar to the NA-50 that were designated '''NA-68'''. The changes in the NA-68 included a modified landing gear, new outer wings, heavier armament, and redesigned tail surfaces similar to those adopted on later production trainers. North American test pilot Lewis Waite flew the first NA-68 on 1 September 1940. ==Operational history== [[File:USAAC P-64.jpg|thumb|right|USAAC P-64]] Peru purchased seven aircraft for the [[Air Force of Peru|Peruvian Air Force]], with deliveries completed in May 1939. In Peruvian service, these aircraft were fitted with bomb racks under the [[fuselage]] for light bombs. The Peruvian NA-50s took part in the [[Ecuadorian-Peruvian war]] of July 1941, supporting [[Army of Peru]] ground forces.Cooper, Tom Cooper and Esteban Rivera.[http://www.acig.org/artman/publish/article_164.shtml "The Most Powerful Air Force in Latin America."] ''Acig.org'', 1 September 2003. Retrieved: 26 March 2010. In 1940, the NA-68s (along with a parallel order for [[North American A-27|NA-69 two seaters]]) ordered by the [[Royal Thai Air Force]] were en route to [[Thailand]] when their export clearance was cancelled and were returned to the United States where they were assigned the designation P-64, disarmed, and used for advanced fighter training. ==Operators== ;{{Flag|Peru}} * [[Peruvian Air Force]] ;{{USA}} * [[United States Army Air Corps]]/[[United States Army Air Forces]] ==Survivors== * NA-50 ''XXI-41-3'' (c/n 50-950). One of the original seven NA-50s built is displayed on a pedestal in front of the [[Museo Aeronáutico del Perú]] at [[Las Palmas Air Base]], [[Lima]], [[Peru]], next to the Mausoleum of Captain [[José Quiñones Gonzáles]], (a Peruvian hero who died flying an NA-50). This example was initially assigned to Escuadrón de Aviación No.1 (Chiclayo Field) and was later transferred to the 28th Advanced Fighter Training Group, 4th squadron until retired in 1967.Hanson, David. [http://www.daveswarbirds.com/usplanes/american.htm "NA-50A XXI-41-3 history."] ''daveswarbirds.com''. Retrieved: 26 March 2010. * NA-68A ''41-19085'' (c/n 68-3061). One of the six intercepted Thailand-bound P-64s which survived being used for training and liaison is now displayed at the [[EAA AirVenture]] Museum. This aircraft has been restored to flying condition, with the engine running again in 2013, followed by its first flying appearance at the 2016 EAA AirVenture Oshkosh airshow. ==Specifications (NA-68/P-64)== {{Aircraft specifications |plane or copter?=plane |jet or prop?=prop |ref={{Citation needed|date=April 2010}} |crew=One |length main=27 ft |length alt=8.23 m |span main=37 ft 3 in |span alt=11.35 m |height main=19 ft 8 in |height alt=5.99 m |area main= |area alt= |empty weight main=4,660 lb |empty weight alt=2,114 kg |loaded weight main=5,990 lb |loaded weight alt=2,717 kg |max takeoff weight main=6,800 lb |max takeoff weight alt=3,080 kg |more general= |engine (prop)=[[Wright R-1820]]-G5 |type of prop=[[radial engine]] |number of props=1 |power main=950 hp |power alt=708 kW |max speed main={{convert|295|mph|km/h}} |max speed alt= |max speed more=at 8,700 ft (2,650 m) |range main= |range alt=1,550 km |ceiling main=27,500 ft |ceiling alt=8,400 m |climb rate main= |climb rate alt= |loading main=26 lb/ft² |loading alt=/m² |power/mass main=0.13 hp/lb |power/mass alt=0.21 kW/kg |more performance= |armament= * 4 × .30 in (7.62 mm) machine guns (2 synchronized in the nose, 1 in each wing) * 2 × [[ caliber|20 mm]] cannons (Located in pods beneath each wing) * Up to 400 lb (181 kg) of bombs }} ==See also== {{Aircontent ||related= * [[North American NA-16]] * [[North American A-27]] * [[North American T-6 Texan]] * [[CAC Boomerang]] – an Australian fighter based on a license-built variant of the T-6 |similar aircraft= *[[Brewster F2A Buffalo]] *[[Curtiss P-36 Hawk]] *[[PZL.50 Jastrząb]] *[[Polikarpov I-180]] *[[Republic P-43 Lancer]] |lists= * [[List of military aircraft of the United States]] * [[List of aircraft of World War II]] |see also= }} ==References== ===Notes=== {{Reflist}} ===Bibliography=== {{Refbegin}} * Green, William. ''War Planes of the Second World War - Fighters (Vol 4)''. London: MacDonald, 1961. {{Refend}} ==External links== {{commons category}} * [http://www.eaa.org/eaa/event/Wednesday_Night_Air_Show?id=138DDA54D9F04C73945B01904A0531B2 WEDNESDAY NIGHT AIR SHOW] * [http://www.eaa.org/en/eaa/eaa-news-and-aviation-news/eaa/2013-02-11-p-64-runs-for-first-time-in-decades P-64 Runs for First Time in Decades] * [http://www.eaa.org/en/eaa-museum/museum-collection/aircraft-collection-folder/1940-north-american-p-64-na-50---n840 Airventure Museum: North American P-64/NA-50 – N840] * [http://www.joebaugher.com/usaf_fighters/p64.html North American P-64] {{North American Aviation aircraft}} {{USAF fighters}} {{DEFAULTSORT:North American P-64}} [[Category:United States fighter aircraft 1940–1949]] [[Category:North American Aviation aircraft]]
